  16. (** Facilities for printing exceptions and inspecting current call stack. *)

  18. ‌type t = exn = ..
  19. (** The type of exception values. *)

  21. ‌val to_string: exn -> string
  22. (** [Printexc.to_string e] returns a string representation of
  23.    the exception [e]. *)

  25. ‌val to_string_default: exn -> string
  26. (** [Printexc.to_string_default e] returns a string representation of the
  27.     exception [e], ignoring all registered exception printers.
  28.     @since 4.09
  29. *)

  31. ‌val print: ('a -> 'b) -> 'a -> 'b
  32. (** [Printexc.print fn x] applies [fn] to [x] and returns the result.
  33.    If the evaluation of [fn x] raises any exception, the
  34.    name of the exception is printed on standard error output,
  35.    and the exception is raised again.
  36.    The typical use is to catch and report exceptions that
  37.    escape a function application. *)

  39. ‌val catch: ('a -> 'b) -> 'a -> 'b
  40. [@@ocaml.deprecated "This function is no longer needed."]
  41. (** [Printexc.catch fn x] is similar to {!Printexc.print}, but
  42.    aborts the program with exit code 2 after printing the
  43.    uncaught exception.  This function is deprecated: the runtime
  44.    system is now able to print uncaught exceptions as precisely
  45.    as [Printexc.catch] does.  Moreover, calling [Printexc.catch]
  46.    makes it harder to track the location of the exception
  47.    using the debugger or the stack backtrace facility.
  48.    So, do not use [Printexc.catch] in new code.  *)

  50. ‌val print_backtrace: out_channel -> unit
  51. (** [Printexc.print_backtrace oc] prints an exception backtrace
  52.     on the output channel [oc].  The backtrace lists the program
  53.     locations where the most-recently raised exception was raised
  54.     and where it was propagated through function calls.

  56.     If the call is not inside an exception handler, the returned
  57.     backtrace is unspecified. If the call is after some
  58.     exception-catching code (before in the handler, or in a when-guard
  59.     during the matching of the exception handler), the backtrace may
  60.     correspond to a later exception than the handled one.

  62.     @since 3.11
  63. *)

  65. ‌val get_backtrace: unit -> string
  66. (** [Printexc.get_backtrace ()] returns a string containing the
  67.     same exception backtrace that [Printexc.print_backtrace] would
  68.     print. Same restriction usage than {!print_backtrace}.
  69.     @since 3.11
  70. *)

  72. ‌val record_backtrace: bool -> unit
  73. (** [Printexc.record_backtrace b] turns recording of exception backtraces
  74.     on (if [b = true]) or off (if [b = false]).  Initially, backtraces
  75.     are not recorded, unless the [b] flag is given to the program
  76.     through the [OCAMLRUNPARAM] variable.
  77.     @since 3.11
  78. *)

  80. ‌val backtrace_status: unit -> bool
  81. (** [Printexc.backtrace_status()] returns [true] if exception
  82.     backtraces are currently recorded, [false] if not.
  83.     @since 3.11
  84. *)

  86. ‌val register_printer: (exn -> string option) -> unit
  87. (** [Printexc.register_printer fn] registers [fn] as an exception
  88.     printer.  The printer should return [None] or raise an exception
  89.     if it does not know how to convert the passed exception, and [Some
  90.     s] with [s] the resulting string if it can convert the passed
  91.     exception. Exceptions raised by the printer are ignored.

  93.     When converting an exception into a string, the printers will be invoked
  94.     in the reverse order of their registrations, until a printer returns
  95.     a [Some s] value (if no such printer exists, the runtime will use a
  96.     generic printer).

  98.     When using this mechanism, one should be aware that an exception backtrace
  99.     is attached to the thread that saw it raised, rather than to the exception
  100.     itself. Practically, it means that the code related to [fn] should not use
  101.     the backtrace if it has itself raised an exception before.
  102.     @since 3.11.2
  103. *)

  105. ‌val use_printers: exn -> string option
  106. (** [Printexc.use_printers e] returns [None] if there are no registered
  107.     printers and [Some s] with else as the resulting string otherwise.
  108.     @since 4.09
  109. *)

  111. (** {1 Raw backtraces} *)

  113. ‌type raw_backtrace
  114. (** The type [raw_backtrace] stores a backtrace in a low-level format,
  115.     which can be converted to usable form using [raw_backtrace_entries]
  116.     and [backtrace_slots_of_raw_entry] below.

  118.     Converting backtraces to [backtrace_slot]s is slower than capturing the
  119.     backtraces. If an application processes many backtraces, it can be useful
  120.     to use [raw_backtrace] to avoid or delay conversion.

  122.     Raw backtraces cannot be marshalled. If you need marshalling, you
  123.     should use the array returned by the [backtrace_slots] function of
  124.     the next section.

  126.     @since 4.01
  127. *)

  129. ‌type raw_backtrace_entry = private int
  130. (** A [raw_backtrace_entry] is an element of a [raw_backtrace].

  132.     Each [raw_backtrace_entry] is an opaque integer, whose value is not stable
  133.     between different programs, or even between different runs of the same
  134.     binary.

  136.     A [raw_backtrace_entry] can be converted to a usable form using
  137.     [backtrace_slots_of_raw_entry] below. Note that, due to inlining, a
  138.     single [raw_backtrace_entry] may convert to several [backtrace_slot]s.
  139.     Since the values of a [raw_backtrace_entry] are not stable, they cannot
  140.     be marshalled. If they are to be converted, the conversion must be done
  141.     by the process that generated them.

  143.     Again due to inlining, there may be multiple distinct raw_backtrace_entry
  144.     values that convert to equal [backtrace_slot]s. However, if two
  145.     [raw_backtrace_entry]s are equal as integers, then they represent the same
  146.     [backtrace_slot]s.

  148.     @since 4.12 *)

  150. ‌val raw_backtrace_entries : raw_backtrace -> raw_backtrace_entry array
  151. (** @since 4.12 *)

  153. ‌val get_raw_backtrace: unit -> raw_backtrace
  154. (** [Printexc.get_raw_backtrace ()] returns the same exception
  155.     backtrace that [Printexc.print_backtrace] would print, but in
  156.     a raw format. Same restriction usage than {!print_backtrace}.

  158.     @since 4.01
  159. *)

  161. ‌val print_raw_backtrace: out_channel -> raw_backtrace -> unit
  162. (** Print a raw backtrace in the same format
  163.     [Printexc.print_backtrace] uses.

  165.     @since 4.01
  166. *)

  168. ‌val raw_backtrace_to_string: raw_backtrace -> string
  169. (** Return a string from a raw backtrace, in the same format
  170.     [Printexc.get_backtrace] uses.

  172.     @since 4.01
  173. *)

  175. external raise_with_backtrace: exn -> raw_backtrace -> 'a
  176.   = "%raise_with_backtrace"
  177. (** Reraise the exception using the given raw_backtrace for the
  178.     origin of the exception

  180.     @since 4.05
  181. *)

  183. (** {1 Current call stack} *)

  185. external get_callstack: int -> raw_backtrace = "caml_get_current_callstack"
  186. (** [Printexc.get_callstack n] returns a description of the top of the
  187.     call stack on the current program point (for the current thread),
  188.     with at most [n] entries.  (Note: this function is not related to
  189.     exceptions at all, despite being part of the [Printexc] module.)

  191.     @since 4.01
  192. *)

  194. (** {1 Uncaught exceptions} *)

  196. val default_uncaught_exception_handler: exn -> raw_backtrace -> unit
  197. (** [Printexc.default_uncaught_exception_handler] prints the exception and
  198.     backtrace on standard error output.

  200.     @since 4.11
  201. *)

  203. val set_uncaught_exception_handler: (exn -> raw_backtrace -> unit) -> unit
  204. (** [Printexc.set_uncaught_exception_handler fn] registers [fn] as the handler
  205.     for uncaught exceptions. The default handler is
  206.     {!Printexc.default_uncaught_exception_handler}.

  208.     Note that when [fn] is called all the functions registered with
  209.     {!Stdlib.at_exit} have already been called. Because of this you must
  210.     make sure any output channel [fn] writes on is flushed.

  212.     Also note that exceptions raised by user code in the interactive toplevel
  213.     are not passed to this function as they are caught by the toplevel itself.

  215.     If [fn] raises an exception, both the exceptions passed to [fn] and raised
  216.     by [fn] will be printed with their respective backtrace.

  218.     @since 4.02
  219. *)


  222. (** {1 Manipulation of backtrace information}

  224.     These functions are used to traverse the slots of a raw backtrace
  225.     and extract information from them in a programmer-friendly format.
  226. *)

  228. ‌type backtrace_slot
  229. (** The abstract type [backtrace_slot] represents a single slot of
  230.     a backtrace.

  232.     @since 4.02
  233. *)

  235. ‌val backtrace_slots : raw_backtrace -> backtrace_slot array option
  236. (** Returns the slots of a raw backtrace, or [None] if none of them
  237.     contain useful information.

  239.     In the return array, the slot at index [0] corresponds to the most
  240.     recent function call, raise, or primitive [get_backtrace] call in
  241.     the trace.

  243.     Some possible reasons for returning [None] are as follow:
  244.     - none of the slots in the trace come from modules compiled with
  245.     debug information ([-g])
  246.     - the program is a bytecode program that has not been linked with
  247.     debug information enabled ([ocamlc -g])

  249.     @since 4.02
  250. *)

  252. ‌val backtrace_slots_of_raw_entry :
  253.   raw_backtrace_entry -> backtrace_slot array option
  254. (** Returns the slots of a single raw backtrace entry, or [None] if this
  255.     entry lacks debug information.

  257.     Slots are returned in the same order as [backtrace_slots]: the slot
  258.     at index [0] is the most recent call, raise, or primitive, and
  259.     subsequent slots represent callers.

  261.     @since 4.12
  262. *)


  265. ‌type location = {
  266.   filename : string;
  267.   line_number : int;
  268.   start_char : int;
  269.   end_char : int;
  270. }
  271. (** The type of location information found in backtraces. [start_char]
  272.     and [end_char] are positions relative to the beginning of the
  273.     line.

  275.     @since 4.02
  276. *)

  278. (** @since 4.02 *)
  279. module Slot : sig
  280.   type t = backtrace_slot

  282. ‌  val is_raise : t -> bool
  283.   (** [is_raise slot] is [true] when [slot] refers to a raising
  284.       point in the code, and [false] when it comes from a simple
  285.       function call.

  287.       @since 4.02
  288.   *)

  290. ‌  val is_inline : t -> bool
  291.   (** [is_inline slot] is [true] when [slot] refers to a call
  292.       that got inlined by the compiler, and [false] when it comes from
  293.       any other context.

  295.       @since 4.04
  296.   *)

  298. ‌  val location : t -> location option
  299.   (** [location slot] returns the location information of the slot,
  300.       if available, and [None] otherwise.

  302.       Some possible reasons for failing to return a location are as follow:
  303.       - the slot corresponds to a compiler-inserted raise
  304.       - the slot corresponds to a part of the program that has not been
  305.       compiled with debug information ([-g])

  307.       @since 4.02
  308.   *)

  310. ‌  val name : t -> string option
  311.   (** [name slot] returns the name of the function or definition
  312.       enclosing the location referred to by the slot.

  314.       [name slot] returns None if the name is unavailable, which
  315.       may happen for the same reasons as [location] returning None.

  317.       @since 4.11
  318.   *)

  320. ‌  val format : int -> t -> string option
  321.   (** [format pos slot] returns the string representation of [slot] as
  322.       [raw_backtrace_to_string] would format it, assuming it is the
  323.       [pos]-th element of the backtrace: the [0]-th element is
  324.       pretty-printed differently than the others.

  326.       Whole-backtrace printing functions also skip some uninformative
  327.       slots; in that case, [format pos slot] returns [None].

  329.       @since 4.02
  330.   *)
  331. end


  334. (** {1 Raw backtrace slots} *)

  336. ‌type raw_backtrace_slot
  337. (** This type is used to iterate over the slots of a [raw_backtrace].
  338.     For most purposes, [backtrace_slots_of_raw_entry] is easier to use.

  340.     Like [raw_backtrace_entry], values of this type are process-specific and
  341.     must absolutely not be marshalled, and are unsafe to use for this reason
  342.     (marshalling them may not fail, but un-marshalling and using the result
  343.     will result in undefined behavior).

  345.     Elements of this type can still be compared and hashed: when two elements
  346.     are equal, then they represent the same source location (the converse is not
  347.     necessarily true in presence of inlining, for example).

  349.     @since 4.02
  350. *)

  352. ‌val raw_backtrace_length : raw_backtrace -> int
  353. (** [raw_backtrace_length bckt] returns the number of slots in the
  354.     backtrace [bckt].

  356.     @since 4.02
  357. *)

  359. ‌val get_raw_backtrace_slot : raw_backtrace -> int -> raw_backtrace_slot
  360. (** [get_raw_backtrace_slot bckt pos] returns the slot in position [pos] in the
  361.     backtrace [bckt].

  363.     @since 4.02
  364. *)

  366. ‌val convert_raw_backtrace_slot : raw_backtrace_slot -> backtrace_slot
  367. (** Extracts the user-friendly [backtrace_slot] from a low-level
  368.     [raw_backtrace_slot].

  370.     @since 4.02
  371. *)


  374. ‌val get_raw_backtrace_next_slot :
  375.     raw_backtrace_slot -> raw_backtrace_slot option
  376. (** [get_raw_backtrace_next_slot slot] returns the next slot inlined, if any.

  378.     Sample code to iterate over all frames (inlined and non-inlined):
  379.     {[
  380.       (* Iterate over inlined frames *)
  381.       let rec iter_raw_backtrace_slot f slot =
  382.         f slot;
  383.         match get_raw_backtrace_next_slot slot with
  384.         | None -> ()
  385.         | Some slot' -> iter_raw_backtrace_slot f slot'

  387.       (* Iterate over stack frames *)
  388.       let iter_raw_backtrace f bt =
  389.         for i = 0 to raw_backtrace_length bt - 1 do
  390.           iter_raw_backtrace_slot f (get_raw_backtrace_slot bt i)
  391.         done
  392.     ]}

  394.     @since 4.04
  395. *)

  397. (** {1 Exception slots} *)

  399. ‌val exn_slot_id: exn -> int
  400. (** [Printexc.exn_slot_id] returns an integer which uniquely identifies
  401.     the constructor used to create the exception value [exn]
  402.     (in the current runtime).

  404.     @since 4.02
  405. *)

  407. ‌val exn_slot_name: exn -> string
  408. (** [Printexc.exn_slot_name exn] returns the internal name of the constructor
  409.     used to create the exception value [exn].

  411.     @since 4.02
  412. *)

  414. (**/**)

  416. (**  {1 Obj printer}
  417.   Unsafe printer used in this module and exposed to the other standard library
  418.    module
  419. *)

  421. ‌val string_of_extension_constructor: Obj.t -> string
